question: Grandiosity is a hallmark of which of the following conditions?
How long must symptoms persist to warrant a diagnosis of depression?
Which of the following are cardinal symptoms of depression?

answers.option: Lack of insight, disorganized speech, and auditory hallucinations
Low mood, lack of interest in activities, and lack of energy
Obsessive intrusive thoughts and repetitive behavior
Delusions, lack of insight, and hallucinations

question: A 60-year-old male with a past medical history of schizophrenia controlled by antipsychotics presents to the emergency department with complaints of high-grade fever, sweating, shortness of breath, and muscle stiffness. What is the likely diagnosis?
According to the International Classification of Diseases 10th Revision (ICD-10) classification, which of the following is the most typical complaint seen in depression?

answers.option: Loss of interest or pleasure in activities

question: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the outpatient department (OPD) by his mother. She reports that her son hears voices that are not real, and faces problems making and keeping friends over the past 6 months. She also mentions how he has been feeling low, stopped taking an interest in his hobbies, and generally lazes about stating he no longer has the energy to carry out simple tasks. What is the likely diagnosis?
An 8-year-old child is brought to the clinic by his parents with the complaint of inattention and inability to sit in the class. What is the probable diagnosis?
Which of the following disorder is not a risk factor for suicide?
Which of these conditions is the greatest risk factor for suicide?
Which of the following anxiety disorders comprises of specific conditions?
Excessive autonomic activation is a feature of which of the following?
What is the pathophysiology of depressive disorder?
Which of these is the most important risk factor for suicide worldwide?
What is the global burden of neuropsychiatric disorders?
Which of these best defines hyperactivity?
Which of the following is a screening questionnaire for alcohol use disorder?

answers.option: Clinical institute withdrawal assessment of alcohol

question: At a family gathering, a 19-year-old male is observed talking and laughing excessively and speaking about working on an invention that will change the world. His brother tells you his behavior has changed over the past 3 weeks; he hardly sleeps, listens to songs all night long, and gets violent at times. He was previously a shy person who seldom met anyone and has never behaved this way before. What is the most likely condition he is suffering from?

A 45-year-old lady who has had a history of regular alcohol intake for the last five years starts hearing voices. The voices discuss the intention to kill her. She also sees the faces of deceased relatives. On inquiry, she also reports disturbed sleep and low mood. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old married man presents to the emergency room with coarse tremors and visual hallucinations. He is unable to identify his family members. When asked about the time of the day he gives an incorrect answer. He also gives vague answers on the hospital whereabouts. Detailed history reveals regular and heavy alcohol intake for the last 10 years. On examination his pulse is 100/min, blood pressure is 150/95 mm Hg and respiratory rate of 32 per min. There are no focal neurological deficits. What is the most probable diagnosis?

A 19-year-old male is brought by his father to the psychiatry clinic with complaints of singing out loud throughout the night, sleeplessness, and claiming he is a famous singer. He had one similar episode in the past and one previous episode with symptoms of low energy and mood, for which he received treatment and reached a pre-morbid level of functionality. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 78-year-old man with generalized anxiety disorder and mild dementia visits his primary care physician. Physical examination of the heart, lungs, and abdomen are unremarkable. Which of the following would be the best treatment option for his generalized anxiety disorder?
What type of schizophrenia shows spasticity?
Which of these is clasically seen in anxiety disorders?
If a person survives after a suicide attempt, what is it called?

A 10-year-old boy is brought to the doctor by his parents with the complaint that he gets angry and frequently beats other children up at school. He also leaves school at times. What is the most likely diagnosis?

The parents of a 7-year-old boy bring him to the clinic because of concerns about his recent behavior in school and at home. In the first grade, he is unable to sit still in class and moves and talks excessively. At home, he cannot sit still at the dining table and often interrupts his parents' conversations. What is the tentative diagnosis?

A 10-year-old boy is referred to a psychologist with complaints of extreme aggression towards his classmates, stealing others' belongings, manipulating his teachers and parents, and has also run away from school 2-3 times. What is the diagnosis in this boy?

For many months a 36-year-old man struggled silently. He dealt with a combination of work, family, and personal issues including the way he perceived himself. He developed anxiety and began cutting and scratching himself, punching, and hitting walls to cope with his emotional pain, intense anger, and frustration. What is the most likely behavior of this man?

answers.option: Solve his stresses by keeping his emotional wellbeing intact

question: A 54-year-old male who has a history of asthma complains of abdominal pain for 6 months and feels something is really wrong with him. He feels a mass in his abdomen. All investigations are normal, endoscopy is done twice and comes back normal. A CT scan of the abdomen is also normal. What is the diagnosis in this case?
Which of the following is the most common cause of dementia?
Which of the following risk factors is most commonly associated with patients requiring long-term treatment for depression?
Which of the following anti-depressants has a stronger risk of self-harm and suicide?

A 16-year-old girl is brought by her mother to the psychiatry clinic with concerns regarding her behavior for 2 weeks. She has stopped going to school and stays in her room the entire day. She refuses to eat food and claims that it has been poisoned. She also believes that her family has installed cameras in her room to keep a close eye on her. She has stopped interacting with her friends and family. What is the likely diagnosis?
Which among the following is/are biological symptoms of depression?

A 27-year-old girl stated to her doctor that, "I was walking with my dog in the park suddenly, I started sweating. Since it isn't hot outside, I couldn't quite understand why...then I started having trouble breathing and really got scared. My heart was pounding so hard I thought it might explode out of my chest. My knees felt weak - it seemed like my whole body was shaking, then my arms went numb. Apparently the whole thing only lasted a few minutes, but it felt like each second was an hour. Did I have a heart attack? Am I going crazy? I felt like I was going to die." What is the most likely diagnosis in that girl?

A 30-year-old male, when leaving his house in the morning, always has to check the door multiple times to make sure that he has locked his front door. If he tries to leave his house without checking his door, or after only checking it once, he is filled with such anxiety and dread that he must abandon whatever else he is doing to return home and check his front door again. What is the most likely phenomenon this man is struggling with?

Parents of a 10-year-old boy are concerned that their child might be suffering from attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Therefore, they brought him to a psychologist for a detailed assessment. Which behavior is most likely consistent with his diagnosis?

answers.option: The child lacks empathy for others
The child engages in self destructive behavior
The child has been hoarding objects

question: A 17-year-old male is brought by his parents to a psychiatric clinic with 3 months history of isolation, poor self-care, self-talking, and refusing to go out. He has a past history of using cannabis. What is the most likely diagnosis of this boy?

A 50-year-old female is brought by her daughter to a psychiatric clinic with complaints of headache, poor sleep, reduced energy, and lack of interest in her life along with suicidal thoughts for the last few months. What is the most likely important feature in her history to make a probable diagnosis?

answers.option: History of similar illness in family

question: A 14-year-old girl who took an overdose of paracetamol in the context of being called fat at school is brought to the emergency department. What is the most important assessment in this case?

A 25-year-old female presents to the clinic with a complaint of low energy levels throughout the day. Further questioning reveals that she also has a persistent low mood and a lack of interest in things she used to enjoy. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 27-year-old nurse presented with occupational dysfunction and loss of interest in her hobbies for 2 months. She was convinced that she would not be able to work again nor would pursue her hobbies of trekking and painting. Recently, she broke up a relationship with her husband. She thought that her life was not worth living and had consumed 60 tablets of phenobarbitone to end her life. She is most likely suffering from which of the following?

A 26-year-old female is brought to the emergency department with symptoms of aggression, over-talkativeness, hyperactivity, and decreased sleep for one week. Her family reveals that she has had two similar episodes in the past 3 years, for which she received treatment. A diagnosis of bipolar affective disorder with a current episode of mania was made. Which of the following groups of medications would be suitable for treatment in this case?

A 35-year-old female patient presents with complaints of restlessness, sweating, tachycardia, and difficulty in breathing for 1 month. These symptoms are episodic. There is a family history of hypertension. Laboratory investigation shows a normal level of vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) in urine. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A 25-year-old woman suffers from insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus. She has been thoroughly informed on how to use insulin and what her diet should be. Furthermore, she is an intelligent girl who understands all of this. Nonetheless, at times, she secretly stops her insulin for no clear external gain like missing a test, and takes in too many carbohydrate-containing foods and drinks that necessitate emergency treatment. Because this behavior is secretive, her doctors wonder what they are doing wrong regarding her treatment. The patient herself seems very forgiving, tells them that she knows they are doing their best, and seems to enjoy the attention of doctors and nurses. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this case?

A 27-year-old electrical engineer is brought to the psychiatric unit involuntarily by his friend, who found a handwritten note in his apartment expressing feelings of hopelessness and despair, suggesting he might be contemplating ending his life. He recently lost his job and going through a crisis in his family. Which of the following is the most appropriate management step for this patient?

answers.option: Assess the capacity of the patient

question: A 30-year-old man visited a psychiatric OPD with episodic illness for the last 5 years. He is on treatment with mood stabilizers and antipsychotics. What could be the possible diagnosis?

An 18-year-old girl presents with complaints of frequent, involuntary motor acts of clapping and head-shaking that have significantly disrupted her daily life for 2-3 months. She also reports having an urge to perform these behaviors to relieve tension and finds temporary relief after doing so. There is no history of substance abuse, and her neurological examination is unremarkable. Which of the following findings would most likely support a diagnosis of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) over a neurological disorder?

answers.option: Childhood history of fever and excessive motor activity
Repetitive behaviors performed to reduce anxiety
Impaired functioning and quality of life
Uncontrollable urge to perform motor tasks
